reviewText:
Full disclosure to start with: I was a Kickstarter backer for this game.

Let me also get this out of the way: I'm not really a horror game fan.  I'm fascinated by the idea of horror games (as the fact that I have a number of horror games on my playlist will attest), but often lack the guts to actually install and play the silly things (as the fact that most of those same games have 0 playtime on them will attest).

Given that, it was with a bit of apprehension that I loaded up the game this evening.  But I went all in for the experience.  The lights were out, the headphones were on, and I dived in.

And I got to say that I enjoyed it.

Neverending Nightmares tells the story of young Thomas, an asthmatic young man whom awakes from a nightmare in which his murders his younger sister, Gabriella.  As the name implies, that is not going to the last time that Thomas wakes up in this game.  Most of the game is spent wandering through a handful of environments, while the tension slowly builds around you.  I’m sure there will be people who decry this as “yet another walking simulator,” as Thomas cannot run for long before having to stop to catch his breath.  This exploration is punctuated by a handful of enemies, and a number of jump scares (I think all but one actually made me jump).  The enemies themselves act more as barriers than as active hunters (with a pretty notable exception), but nothing too aggravating to overcome.  The real draw here is the tense atmosphere.

The tension is brought in large part by some amazing sound design.  The ambient soundtrack kept me on edge pretty much the entire time.  The enemy tells were also nerve-racking…and while not sound design, I wanted to give a shout out to some great use of controller vibration, using it to as another cue for the enemy’s footsteps.  Even the sound of poor Thomas gasping and wheezing to catch his breath after a full sprint was well done.  It made me feel bad for the poor kid, and I actually stopped sprinting as much because I didn’t want to hear it anymore!

In the end, Neverending Nightmares is a short game.  I finished my first play through in an hour and a half.  There are a couple a sequences that I missed and intend to go back and play through, but all told I’ll be surprised if a full complete takes more than 2 hours (Update: it took me 2.5 hours to get all endings/branches).  In the past, that has been a major hang up for me.  In this case of Nightmares, however, I don’t mind at all.  I feel that I got my full-pledge value out of what I played.  It's a tight experience that delivers it's narritive and atmosphere, and then ends before it overstays it welcome. And I wouldn’t be surprised if Neverending Nightmares becomes a Halloween tradition for me.

I also feel that the story behind the game is an important one.  The game is the director’s way of trying to express what it was like for him to suffer from depression and OCD.  But don’t worry, this isn’t a “game with a message” where you are beaten over the head with it.  It did cause me to consider what it must be like to suffer from mental illness when, after I played the game, I discovered that some of the more gory/horrific sequences in the game were inspired by intrusive thoughts the director had suffered from (I didn't even know about intrusive thoughts before then, if I am being painfully honest).  If you google 'Neverending Nightmares,' you will get linked to some articles where the director tells his story and his reasons behind the game in more detail than my lame attempt here.  It is well worth looking up.

All told, I don't regret throwing my money behind Neverending Nightmares at all.  If you like horror games, pick it up.


Update:
I managed to reach all the endings.  According to Steam, this took me about 2.5 hours (on timer on Steam said 2, another said 3, so I'll spilt the difference).  I should note that, after I played through blind the first time, I used a guide to find the other two endings, so if you are keen on finding out those for yourself, it might take long.

reviewText:
Neverending Nightmares is a game that puts the writing on the wall (in blood) and counts on your subconscious to fill in the details. This effect builds a lot of tension in the beginning of the game but as you move through the levels the lack of clarity makes it hard to tell if you are progressing in the true sense of the word. Is the ambiguity part of the horror of being lost within your own mind? Of not knowing what the right move is? Perhaps, but the more readily apparent consequence is that by never reaching a moment of hope or a moment of achievement that becomes more than not failing... your control of Thomas starts to feel impersonal and monsters begin to look more like mechanics than terrors of the mind.

But does any of this mean the game is a failure? The cynic in me might say yes, but he'd be proven wrong pretty easily. I spent a lot of time wanting to understand the world I was in, a lot of time jumping up a couple of feet and a lot of time engrossed in the atmosphere crafted through a unique and eerie art style and a haunting soundtrack. Considering one branch of three endings can be completed in under two hours, I think that speaks volumes of the quality of production.

As a kickstarter backer I'm satisfied with my purchase and I have a lot of respect for the developer, but this is a flavour of horror unique enough that a universal recommendation as a must-play would be poor advice for those who hunger after simpler dishes. For a certain group of gamers Neverending Nightmares will hit the spot - for those curious ones.
This game was so obviously crafted with love and an insane attention to detail that for the sake of everyone else I hope Matt Gilgenbach can bring his talents to bear on a future project with more readable progression.

Neverending Nightmares is an ode to uncertainty and I suspect my own perception of its meaning may shift with more playthroughs. If you're in an adventurous mood for confusion and like your atmosphere served rare, jump in - the blood's nice and warm.

reviewText: Neverending Nightmares does a fine job of capturing the shifting scenery and helpless dread of nightmares, and it does so with only a handful of actual monsters -- the real horror comes from the gorgeous, Edward Gorey-esque artwork and the rich audio, which work together to mount a terrifying tension.  The ending levels are quite different depending on which path you choose, making it worthwhile to achieve all three endings.\n\nI do have a few minor complaints.  For $14 I expected the game to be at least 5-6 hours, and I would have liked to have seen more environmental variation and more object interaction.  Additionally, I would have preferred a little more meat on the narrative.  I do understand that all of this would have been quite a tall order for such a beautifully hand-drawn (and atmosphere-focused) indie as Neverending Nightmares.  As it is, the game is a terrific bit of interactive horror and I would love to see Gilgenbach do another, perhaps longer and more involved, game in the same style.

reviewText:
I was a backer to the game. The idea seemed quite interesting at the time, but it didn't turn out well. There is/was no horror - some gore and attempts at jump scares. The plot... well, I'm not really sure there is a plot. Apparently there are different endings, but I have no clue how to obtain them. I'm being told I made choices at some point during the game, but I have no idea when, where or how.

The entire game felt dull, very walking-simulator. I understand this game is supposed to be reflective or symbolic of mental illness, which I can relate to, but if there is some kind of message being communicated, it is completely lost on me.

It is extremely short, but I have to say if it was significantly longer with no other changes, I probably would never finish it simply out of boredom.

The pros of the game are the music and the art. The art is very unique and engaging. Some areas of the sounds get annoying at times (your character gets winded from running 10 feet and huffs as if they were a 50-year smoker) but it does communicate the atmosphere well.

I wouldn't overall recommend it, but I also wouldn't write it off. If you are a overall fan of this style/genre, it's good to kill a couple hours at a cheap price.

reviewText:
Stylistically, this game is great. The art style is amazing and the sound is well done. While not the most scary game, the atmosphere is pretty creepy. While it has a few jump scares, the game doesn't depend on them. This is a game you must play with headphones at night.

That said, the whole package is really underwhelming. There's no combat in the game and the most you do is dodge the few predictable enemies in each section. If you manage to make a mistake, you restart in a room just before the one you died in. The enemy system is unchallenging and annoying, and rather than help the game, it makes it tedious.

The game itself is incredibly short, and you can finish the first playthrough in less than one hour and a half. This isn't even rushing through the game, but exploring and examining the locations. Even getting through all the game routes, it'll be hard to go over three hours. I would be able to forgive this if it wasn't for the game biggest mistake: it's really repetitive. The first hour of the game is, as I said before, creepy and atmospheric. Then the game starts recycling assets and themes and the whole experience falls on its face. In the end you'll get one of three endings, and I'm sad to say, they're just disappointing (short, straightforward and not even clever). There's no reason for a game so short to be this repetitive and saying that it was intended to be that way is a terrible excuse.

I mention that the game has a nice style to it, but there are games that do it much better, and for the current price ($15) it isn't really worth getting it.

reviewText: Not great, but a pretty decent horror romp. The actual scares get very repetitive towards the end as you go through the same rooms and encounter the same enemies over and over and over again. Locations and enemies are unfortunately fairly stock: creepy old mansion, run down asylum, mutilated inmates, living dolls, etc... A few times the enemies actually managed to frighten me, but they were mostly predictable. This game is a fine example of why repetition can ruin horror. All that being said, the audio and visual design save this game from being completely mediocre. The sound in the game reminded me very much of Eternal Darkness, setting the mood of a rapidly shifting nightmare scape very effectively. And the hand drawn, line heavy art style is fantastic. Overall, I'd say it's worth your time, but try to pick it up during a sale.

reviewText:
Neverending Nightmares may be a short experience - taking around two hours to finish - but the paper and ink art style and oppressive atmosphere has combined into a very innovative and interesting game. More reminiscent of Limbo than any of the more conventional horror games I've played, the game creates a dark world with only one objective: keep walking.

Though the third person perspective means that it can't do jump scares as well as most horror games, it nonetheless managed to create a feeling of dread throughout the game by focusing more in the psychological part of the horror genre. The slow building gameplay helps contribute to the dark and introverted feel of the game; though I found it wonderfully refreshing, not all gamers may enjoy what is essentially wandering around a dismal world for half an hour.

Though it suffers from a few minor glitches with the lighting, it never really got in the way of gameplay and the branch-off levels add to the otherwise short game. It gets a little repetitive by the end, and the short environments show its indie background, but it's ultimately worth playing and is infinitely preferable to games like Dead Space which overly rely on jump scares.

reviewText: I've rarely seen a game start off so stellar, then nosedive. and then suddenly be over before it barely got underway. The first half is the most eerie gaming experience I've ever had—despite the abstract artstyle—to the point where I had to shut it off and calm myself down after just 5 minutes. The atmosphere is so well done that the game is worth recommending. Just. The game then changes locale and suddenly swaps out atmosphere for tedious, repetitive scenarios where all you do is elude zombie-type creatures, while you rely mostly on trial-and-error and the frustratingly slow pace of your character, who is exhausted after 5 seconds of sprinting. And then the game is suddenly over— after maybe 1 hour of play. The few interactive items in the game that seemed like maybe pieces to a puzzle, or a secret to unravel (mostly framed portraits) appear to be just things for you to pointlessly look at.\nTo be honest I felt cheated paying what is the equivalent of $17 for this. Grab it during Summer Sale if it's there for like $5 just to experience the remarkably well done opening act, but this game feels like the developer(s) got lazy in a hurry.

reviewText:
I was a backer to the game. The idea seemed quite interesting at the time, but it didn't turn out well. There is/was no horror - some gore and attempts at jump scares. The plot... well, I'm not really sure there is a plot. Apparently there are different endings, but I have no clue how to obtain them. I'm being told I made choices at some point during the game, but I have no idea when, where or how.

The entire game felt dull, very walking-simulator. I understand this game is supposed to be reflective or symbolic of mental illness, which I can relate to, but if there is some kind of message being communicated, it is completely lost on me.

It is extremely short, but I have to say if it was significantly longer with no other changes, I probably would never finish it simply out of boredom.

The pros of the game are the music and the art. The art is very unique and engaging. Some areas of the sounds get annoying at times (your character gets winded from running 10 feet and huffs as if they were a 50-year smoker) but it does communicate the atmosphere well.

I wouldn't overall recommend it, but I also wouldn't write it off. If you are a overall fan of this style/genre, it's good to kill a couple hours at a cheap price.

reviewText:
Stylistically, this game is great. The art style is amazing and the sound is well done. While not the most scary game, the atmosphere is pretty creepy. While it has a few jump scares, the game doesn't depend on them. This is a game you must play with headphones at night.

That said, the whole package is really underwhelming. There's no combat in the game and the most you do is dodge the few predictable enemies in each section. If you manage to make a mistake, you restart in a room just before the one you died in. The enemy system is unchallenging and annoying, and rather than help the game, it makes it tedious.

The game itself is incredibly short, and you can finish the first playthrough in less than one hour and a half. This isn't even rushing through the game, but exploring and examining the locations. Even getting through all the game routes, it'll be hard to go over three hours. I would be able to forgive this if it wasn't for the game biggest mistake: it's really repetitive. The first hour of the game is, as I said before, creepy and atmospheric. Then the game starts recycling assets and themes and the whole experience falls on its face. In the end you'll get one of three endings, and I'm sad to say, they're just disappointing (short, straightforward and not even clever). There's no reason for a game so short to be this repetitive and saying that it was intended to be that way is a terrible excuse.

I mention that the game has a nice style to it, but there are games that do it much better, and for the current price ($15) it isn't really worth getting it.

reviewText:
I would recommend Neverending Nightmares at a discount if you are disappointed by short play-throughs. I, personally, don't care for game+ type of scenarios or running through alternate endings and such which might be something to consider also. With that said I beat the game in 92 minutes and I can say that my overall experience was pretty good.

On the plus side, the sound is notably magnificent. I really like how the directional queues in the audio contributed to the overall awareness of your impending doom. It goes without saying that sound plays a major role in any scary game or game that wants to immerse you. Equally noteworthy is the art style. You may or may not like the hand-drawn aesthetic, but I like it, though it is worth noting the entire game is rendered this way. There are also a lot of explorable areas along the way to take in the detail if you're in the mood to appreciate the labor that has been put into the artwork.

What I didn't like was the repetition. You will get winded after the first 30 minutes when, despite the inclusion of a few evil creatures, you realize the mechanics are a bit shallow. You look at things that have color, you push the shift key to run from creatures, and you try not to walk into the possessed inmates. That is the challenge in a nut shell, though it shouldn't take away from the real goal of delivering an enjoyable story which you can read all about in the game's description (it is pretty accurate).

Neverending Nightmares is a trip, no doubt about it. The game would be a great way to kill an hour or two if not indulged upon in short bites. Check it out some time.

Check out my profile for screenshots of scenes that disturbed me the most!

reviewText:
I'm sorry, but this is one of the most boring and uninspired horror games I've ever played. In the hour and a half it took to get through the game I kept hoping for Anything mildly interesting to happen, but in the end I just felt like I had wasted my time.

You play through a series of nightmares that all consist of walking through corridor upon corridor in such groundbreaking and refreshing settings as ~an old, abandoned house~, ~a psychiatric hospital~, and ~a graveyard~. I expected there to be some absurdity, maybe some surreal looking areas - these are nightmares after all - but there was hardly any to be found.
Occassionally you will come across monsters that you have to get past to get to the next boring corridor. Some you need to hide from, some are blind but will attack if they hear you, etc. Pretty standard horror game mechanics, nothing new here either.

Now, I could live with the boring gameplay and paint-by-the-numbers horror elements if only the game had an interesting story to tell, but even the story is about as trite and clichéd as they come. In the description it says the game was inspired by the creator's struggles with depression and OCD, but I didn't see anything that gave me any insight into what it was like to deal with that.
I say this as someone who's struggling with mental illness myself, and am a little dissapointed that you'd use that as a selling point for something that only ever comes across as yet another horror story about some guy fighting monsters in a surreal alternate world because of a traumatic family incident. It never feels personal at all, it just falls flat.

Also, apparently the game has multiple endnings, but it gives you no reason to want to replay it, so I don't know what the point of that even is.

If you want to play a game where it feels like you're fighting mentall illness, play Knock Knock. If you want to play a game with a similar quirky children's book style, play Fran Bow. Both are much better horror games.

reviewText:
While the aesthetic and sound design is fantastic, Neverending Nightmares is flawed. The use of colour is excellent and I have a weakness for eerie whispers. Later in the game the sparse and occasional blood spatters begin to become the usual décor which loses the promise it once had of violence and horrors.

As for the pacing, we play as a sickly child who can ran for about 5 seconds before he must take a break to wheeze desperately and collect himself. When he isn't breathlessly fumbling along, he staggers at a snails pace. The enemies and threats this game provides feel no more forboding than a slightly deformed picture of a kitten. Interacting with them does not cause fear, but rather it brings the already slow pace to a crawl.

I found myself wanting it to be over but it kept dragging on. The jump scares were predictable and over all it was an unsurprising and tedious experience. I respect the personal nature of this game, and I think it's absolutely awesome for the devolper to use the medium for expression, but as a game, I don't recommend it. Or maybe I'm just jaded and hard to please.

reviewText:
Ok, so there you have the first analisis I wrote about the game the first time I finished it, and at the end my final impressions.

First impressions:

This has to be a joke. Ok, so the art is great, it's very atmospheric and it has some really creepy moments. But you simply can't sell at this price a game that you can complete in an hour. Yes, it has alternate endings, but it means that you are going to have to play the whole game again, a game that is already very repetitive, only to watch another ending but without any new playable experiences.
The game has literally three different kind of hazards and like another three puzzles and that is it.
And let me tell you, what is up with that part with the boy in the woods? it seem only there to annoy the player, the boy can't run for more than like five seconds and even running he is incredibly slow, and they make you run through an endless wood chasing your sister.
And by the way, all that thing that the developers have been telling about the game being  based on the real experiences of someone who have experienced mental illness, so convenient that his condition involve a mental hospital, a creepy house, and all the oldest horror clichés.
Shame on you Infinitap Games.

Final impressions:

Ok, so now I've completed the hundred per cent and played through all of what the game has to offer, you can check my profile to see that it's true, and that I have spent only three hours to accomplish this, considering that I have had to play to some segments more than once.
Here is my conclusion, the game is extremely short and the sceneries and situations are used again and again. Many times, there is not even anything to do, only walk through hallways and hallways, entering rooms that have nothing inside and wait for the jump scares to appear.
The game has a few really good moments, but really keep you waiting for more to come, something that gives sense to the whole experience that never comes. The game suffers from a lack of content, especially considering the price.
I feel very disappointed, because this game had huge possibilities.

reviewText:
Edward Gorey.

One of my favorite artists.  His dark, gothic style of cartooning has delighted the Victorian in people for years.

Now Neverending Nightmares takes his style and makes a game out of it, and just like Goreys style, in this game there are no good endings.

Only black and white is allowed in the pallette, with occasional visits from other colors... particulary red.  A simple mask of blakc lines over the front of the screen gives the omnipresent drearyness  a real sense of depression.  When a color does pop up the players eyes are immediatly drawn to it.

The music fits very well, sound samples are played repeatedly with changes in frequency giving the body of the song rather than pitches or notes.  Whether is a twisted lullaby, or the screams of a lunatic in an asylum every part of this game screams at the player Doom!  Death!  Hoplessness! Despair!" while using a the voice of a soft whisper.

If you love dark things

I briefly watched a stream by SCXCR of RiverCityGamer (woo hoo, shamelessly self-promotion), and got immediately inspired to purchase the game, especially at the ever inticing 10% off sale.  I sat through the game with a pair of stereo headphones on and I have to say, the two things I immediately loved were the graphics style and the sound design. There isn't a lot of variety and the game is pretty linear but does give you branching paths near the end which can change up the narrative. Disclaimer: I know the developer, and am a fan of his work. That said, what's most compelling about the game to me is that it mirrors his own experiences with mental illness:

I am channeling very specific imagery from intrusive thoughts that I've suffered from because of my OCD. Intrusive thoughts are these crazy thoughts that your mind comes up with for the sole purpose of upsetting you. In my case, I've struggled with thoughts of violent self-harm. I've actually re-created some of my visions in the game like pulling the vein out of my arm or tearing out an arm bone.
What's powerful about games is that they give us the opportunity to experience things we normally can't. And in this case, it's not the result of a group of people sitting around a table thinking, What'll scare the player? Hey
recommended: but Matt Gilgenbach's interpreting some of what he's actually gone through."

reviewText: Make no mistake; this is a psychologycal horror game in the truest sense - It's a game that through it's main gameplay loop (an endless awakening into another nightmare) explores the developer's daily struggles of OCD as well as intrusive thoughts. It's all presented in an Edward Gorey-like artstyle, that also brings to mind the works of Edgar Allan Poe. Even more intriguing than it's artstyle is the absolutely fantastic sound design which consantly keeps the player tense for the horrors to come. Is this the scariest horror game I've ever played? Well, no. But like the best games in the psychological horror genre it focuses on being thoroughly unsettling throughout - a feeling that intensifies upon reflecting on the real life mental struggles that inspired it.\n\nCommon complaints target the game's short length and the lack of player interaction - but to me these miss the point. reviewText:
Let me get the general ruling out of the way first: this is a great game from a new and promising voice in the indie horror game scene. It tries new things and often does things by its own rules, and it does this effectively, while also following in the footsteps of tried and true horror classics. It's not for everyone, but fans of personal, artistic, exploratory games as well as fans of atmospheric horror games (as opposed to action/survival-based horror) should buy, enjoy, and support it.

That said, the game is not without its flaws, and a number of them have to do with pacing.

Hallways sometimes seem to go on a touch too long without much happening. It's a strange feeling, getting *bored* by a horror game. Luckily, several times I thought maybe I was started to get bored, something terrifically terrifying would happen and put my ♥♥♥ right back on the edge of my seat where it belonged. Perhaps these moments would not have been as effective without the moments of calm, but I feel that the game would have been *more*, not less, effective if a few of the rooms or hallways would have been cut.

That's not to say that all of the pointless" rooms should be cut. It's kind of wonderful to be walking down what seems like a cookie-cutter hallway

reviewText:
Stylized, creepy and short and MUST be played with both headphones and a game pad with vibration.  Missing either of the latter two will cause you to lose a good 50% of the atmosphere.  Great for Edward Gorey fans.

The game could have been more, and one enemy in particular adds an obnoxious game mechanic which is initially clever and then very tedious.  It also fails to provide any really satisfying endings.

Your enjoyment of Neverinding Nightmares will largely depend on what you look for in a horror game.  Thankfully Slendy -- who showed up in the demo -- is removed from the final version.

If you're the kind of person who enjoys being creeped out, this does a pretty good job.  This isn't a game played for depth, but it does an excellent job with providing a unique experience your first time through.  If the art style doesn't do much for you, chances are the rest of the game won't.  If you enjoy Creepypasta however, this might be up your alley.

Warning for those squeamish about blood and gore: some paths are pretty nasty from an imagery standpoint.

Is it worth the price tag?  Depends on how much you value atmosphere.  I don't regret purchasing it.  If you enjoy Edward Gorey stuff, this might be right up your alley.

reviewText:
My first exposure to this game was a Let's Play by Lotus Prince.  At first glance, this game could easily be dismissed as not scary.  It certaintly doesn't look like a lot of the modern horror games.

Do not let quick impressions fool you, this game is a wonderfully creepy, scary and just disturbing game.

This is definetly a game to play with headphones if you can, the sound design is amazing.  Not only is there a mix of unsettling music, there is also plenty of background sounds that really start to get to you the longer you play.

This is also a game to play in big chunks, the more breaks you take, the more the atmosphere is broken.  If possible, try and play through to a finished path in one sitting.

I've currently gotten all three endings and I won't share any of the details here.

One of the strengths of this game is there is very little to interact with.  Too often horror games have you working on finding puzzle clues or weapons or health items.  This game you are limited what you can interact with.  The lack of busy work really helps draw you into the surroundings, and you'll find things in areas you thought weren't scary yet, slowly starting to disturb you greatly.

It also makes what you CAN interact with, and see more clearly, have that much more impact.

Yes, there are a few moments of jump scares, but this game is a lot more about the nature of being trapped in this nightmare, where you keep thinking you're waking up and escaping, and you're not.

Yes, I was one of the late backers after this game was fully funded and started to play when the Beta was available.  That doesn't make my review or praise for this game any less.  Hell it was seeing the Let's Play that made me want to help be a backer and be a part of this game.

This game has many moments where the sudden disturbing imagery made me turn away, though nothing in the realm of going too far.  Honestly some moments in this game reminded me of nightmares I've had myself, which only added to how emersed I was.

Also, do not seek a strategy guide, you'll figure out all the branches eventually.  Let youself find them alone, it's a much better story that way.

It took me a few times through some areas to figure out how to get the different branch, which helped the game feel very worth the price.

If you like to be scared by more than gore and things jumping out at you, this is game is definetly worth a try.

reviewText:
This game should be called Neverending Jump Scares and Walking. Seriously, all you do in this game is walk, very slowly I might add, and trigger jump scares. The devs added the capability to run but your character can't run more than 10 sec so I guess he's asthmatic.

This game is clearly a personal message from the dev on something happening in his life but that's all it should be, a message, write in a journal and don't make games dude. This is hardly a game but more of a short story and it's not told very well either. I'm glad I got this in a Humble Bundle because I'd be furious if I spent $15 bucks on this. Actually, I'd be upset spending $5.

Good:
-Artwork is fantastic! I really loved the pen and ink feel. The black and white set a very good creepy tone and matched well with the story and setting.
-Music and audio matched up well with everything and felt original for horror music.
-I enjoyed the creature interactions and really liked killing my character off just to see what happens.

Bad:
-At times the artwork was so overwhelming with so many lines especially in the forest. There was nothing creepy about the forest walking scene because I was so frustrated at how long it took to get through WAY TOO MUCH WALKING and how busy the artwork was.
-Boring story. I get the story, I understand it, it was just boring. The characters weren't interesting and the endings were dull.
-TOO MUCH WALKING! Unless I can get something added to the story or some intersting scenes from walking away from the main objective then don't let me walk there. Out of all the cells you could peek into, only one did anything, and that was a very predictable jump scare. If exploration doesn't do anything then stop letting us explore. As a player I expect to find something when I go somewhere, but in this game you don't see anything unless you go towards the main objectives. It's like having a game where the very last room out of 100 has a boss fight but the game lets you enter all other rooms 1-99 but they are empty. What's the point?

TL;DR

I'd give the game a 4 out of 10. It's not something I'd reccomend to anybody unless they simply like original stories regardless of quality.

reviewText:
Pros: The music is pretty good, and there were about two points during the entire experience where I thought the scares/images were effective

Cons: Sadly, aside from those two particular times I found all the rest of it to be dull, cliche set dressings on what were essentially empty rooms and hallways. Seriously, 90% of this game is walking down empty hallways that become more and more cluttered with either gore or eyeless dolls. There are other scary things out there, developer! Gore and dolls can be scary, but you kind of drowned the game in them to the point where they no longer have meaning.

The plot consists of a few 5-10 second long spoken bits which includes the endings. I get that the developer wanted to leave things ambiguous and let the player draw their own conclusions, but the fact that there is no lore to collect and no narrative whatsoever means the player has literally no reason to move through the game.

I wish the developers had put the same amount of effort into making a gripping narrative or lore notes to collect (they're a horror game staple for a reason) or any reason at all to drive players to continue pushing their character down those hallways as they did dressing up the endless, empty rooms with an insane level of detail (sadly most of which is same-y gore and dolls).

This game would be hard to recommend as a free flash game. When I finished it and got all the endings I just felt like I had wasted an afternoon and a few bucks.

reviewText:
Great atmosphere, music, artistic design, etc. If you are a fan of horror, indie games, artistic games, and just want to try something new. You really owe it to yourself to get this game. Ok, hopefully those who don't mind spoiling are still reading at this point. I was originally going to complain a little about this game, at ~$15 it became more expensive than going to a movie. One of the things I appreciate most about video games is from a time vs. money investment usually they make up for their higher price. A first run through of this game took me about 90 minutes. Making this slightly more expensive than a movie. But then as I looked around the menus I discovered there are multiple endings and paths you can take. Giving the game some replayability and making it now worth more than a movie. I'm not sure if you could see the multiple paths before you beat the game the first time (I didn't check) hence the spoiler notice before. So yeah, all in all a really good little game. I'm excited to see what else the team comes up with.

reviewText:
If you're thinking about buying this game, stop it right now and find something else. I'm going to go into full spoiler detail here so if you for some reason still want this 'game' then stop reading and understand it's your own fault for making such a poor choice with you money.

Now spoiler alert, the game is walking to te end of a hallway several times in which if you see a door above you don't wory that's either an empty room or just a checkpoint room. The insta kill enemies (which there are only three kinds of) which are all just a slight variation on the oh so amazing gameplay stratgey of walking around them slowly. The story is nill, you get the impression your sister died when you were young and you're stricken with grief because you promised to keep her safe and that makes you crazy or whatever so you're locked up in a looney bin. I can't stress this enough that there is no game here, the first minute of gameplay is repeated without change until you finish the game. I've played games free flash games with more anything really. TL;DR This isn't a game, and you shouldn't waste your money on it.

I wish the rating system on here would be a little more complex but I shall have to not recommend the game.

Neverending Nightmares had some things going for it. The art style was refreshing despite excessive crosshatching obscuring lots of detail, it's Gothic atmosphere is effective and I did get scared at some points albeit by cheap jump scares but hey whatever works right?

reviewText:
Tedious, frusterating, poorly balanced and overall, not fun.

In terms of good points I'll say the creator has a excellent art style and made sufficently horrifying. Unfortunently thats where the good points end.

You know how most games have distingushing features in their levels and streamline the design so that the player knows where they are in the level design and don't constantly wander back and forth wondering if they're going the right way towards the next object that will progress the plot? Well, this game doesnt, and because of the constant reused assets I kept wondering whether I was going the right way or whether I had inadvertantly backtracked and needed to reverse my course.

In itself that would only be a moderate annoyance, but theres also the issue that the levels have way to much *nothing* in them. Out of the time I spent in the first area, I estimate only about 10% had an event in it, either a scare or a monster or something to do, the rest just being padding going from one room to another.

And when stuff does happen, its not well balanced. In the second area, I wound up having to get from one scene to another without being caught by zombies, but there was no way to tell where the zombies were in the screen other than trial and error, there was no way to lose the zombies if they did spot me due to how slow my character ran, and even if I did know where they were sneaking around them was nearly impossible due to how small the areas were, so I would constantly get caught, die, get sent back to the last checkpoint, repeat ad nausium.

Honestly, this is one of the worst indie games I have bought and played. I cannot recommend it to anyone except horror junkies who've played everything else.

reviewText:
First playthrough time: 2 hours
All endings play time: 3.5 hours total

Major Pros:
Great sound and music
Multiple endings and story paths allow for replayability and story map easily lets you hop to the part you want to play
Good use of some traditional horror themes and restricted vision levels

Minor Pros:
Interesting art and color useage
Pleasant eerie elements background elements give the place a haunted feel, but could've been used more
Jump scares" not overused

Major Cons:
90% of the time you don't need to go in any of the rooms other than the one at the end of the hallway
Some early monsters feel repetitive while others make it feel like an action game (later monsters were much better)
A fair amount of the game is walking through uninteractive scenery

Minor Cons:
The color-bordered pleasant pictures on the walls detract from the creepy atmosphere
Story is a little unclear and might leave player feeling like they still have questions

I found the game very interesting and really liked the art. The different levels and parts of the story
recommended: were very enjoyable. My favorite level is probably when the dolls start coming to life because I felt it gave the player the right amount of anticipation when traveling between rooms. reviewText: This is an interesting game that provides some chilling moments during play.  The story of Thomas Smith, while simple, pretty much makes you think a little, maybe even make your own conspiracy theories.  Both the atmosphere and the sounds give you a chill, and I'm impressed that the game manages to spook you without the use of the over-used jump scare.  There are a few problems, though.  You can finish one of the story modes in no time, I say about 45 minutes to a hour tops, so you might complete the whole game, if not collect all four achievements, with 4-5 hours.  Also, whatever enemies there are in the game aren't the scariest things ever.  You can easily get past them with the most obvious way possible.  Only thing that could make getting past the enemies more obvious was to put in neon signs, and the ones that chase you will give you at least a little bit of a problem.  That being said though, the reason why people play horror games is to get scared, and in that regard, I think it does a good job.  If you're looking for cheap jump scares, like most indie horror games do unfortunately, then this is not the game for you.  Otherwise, this is a game worth experiencing, though the length might effect how much it's worth.

reviewText: This game is extremely atmospheric. While the graphical style is very interesting, what moved me most was the extremely creepy (and intensifying) music as well as the excellent sound assets. However, there is something you definitely need to know: The game is short. Even with branching paths the game only takes a few hours to finish. And it must be said that there is relatively little replayability once all the branches have been unlocked and all the levels played. In light of that, the price point might be an issue for you, so you might want to wait for a sale if you don't mind the wait. However, it's less of an issue if you think of it like a movie in the cinema. A couple hours worth of entertainment for a few bucks, but I can certainly understand if you want to wait for the DVD release to keep the metaphor going. If you pick it up, though, make sure to get the full cinematic experience: Darkened room and headphones. Use a gamepad with rumble if you have it for smoother controls and more feedback. Overall a very enjoyable if short ride.

reviewText:
The subconscious can be a truly dark and frightening place and Neverending Nightmares propels this notion to the forefront. You play as Thomas, seemingly forever stuck in a perpetual nightmare/sleep state. He dreams in black and white, he dreams of death and murder. Creepy broken dolls lay strewn within the walls of his home. He dreams of monochrome tombstones and blood stained asylum walls. But...is he really dreaming? The game forces us to accept dread, fear and vulnerability. Thomas cannot wield weapons, he can't fight. All he (or you) can do is survive.

The gameplay mechanics are very straighforward. Directions, sprint and an interact button. That is all. But do not take this simplicity for inadequacy. The game is very unsettling. The scares are very well crafted and will make you think before making your next move. There are equal parts subtle and obvious scares. Neverending Nightmares is an exercise in psychological horror, throwing you in between worlds and catching you off guard in the process. Cheap jumscares are a thing of the past and Neverending Nightmare gets my vote for progressive horror gaming.

If you're looking for a different kind of horror, the kind of horror that is deep rooted within your subconscious, then this is the game for you. My only regret? Not playing this in online mode, so now I have no achievements. But that's ok because in my opinion Neverending Nightmare has a high replay value and three different endings to keep you entertained (and afraid).

If you'd like to see my take on this brilliant game, go here : http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=lNfGiLomjks&list=PLAiqVOZlx0AhavAEyxjX5XANGj_54ydvq

reviewText:
I was one of the Kickstarter backers for this game, having fallen in love with the initial concept and the teaser trailer. A psychological horror game inspired by the experiences of a man suffering from his own very personal, genuine psychological horror? Count me in. As both a lover of horror and as someone who is fascinated by what makes other people tick, this game seemed a sure-fire hit (to me).

Does is succeed? Sort of. I'm giving this a thumbs-up because I feel emotionally attached to it as both a backer and a horror enthusiast, but I can't say I wasn't a bit let down.

There is very little gameplay to speak of - minor stealth sections are fine, but they grow repetitive quickly. I don't want to write this off as a walking simulator, because 1) I hate that term, and 2) I love walking simulators (Dear Esther, to me, is a stunning work of art). However, there just isn't all that much to this game. Keep walking right. Look at another portrait. Go into another empty room. Wake up in a different bed. Walk right again. Meh.

The best part is the atmosphere. The soundscape is truly stunning. Play this game with headphones, please. I've haven't heard audio this precise and well-designed since the original Thief games. And the visual style is simply gorgeous.

I love thte idea of multiple endings, but slogging through the same corridors three times again to find them all was too much.

Buy it, play once for the phenomenal atmosphere and a few good scares, but don't expect too much from it.

reviewText:
Visuals, atmosphere, and sound were fantastic. Gameplay wise I have mixed feelings. 90% of the entire world in the game is noninteractable (Basically you cannot examine or do anything with most things) so you’re mostly just walking and walking and walking until you find the next scripted event that will progress you to the next part. That can actually get a little dull mainly because you’re stuck with a very very slow walk. You can run but you run out of breath ridiculously quick making me think this dude has asthma or something. So basically you’re kinda forced to go through this game rather slow. Perhaps this was intentional. Maybe the developer wanted us to play the game at a slower pace. But for me I kinda caught early on that there was going to be lots of periods where there are no threats at all.

Clearly this game’s intention is to be more of an experience than like a typical “game” although there are some sections where you have hiding mechanics and stealth mechanics. I’d say I’d like if this game had like written files to pick up and read but I think they’d rather you try and piece things together on your own rather than having the game write it out for you.

Overall I say the developer probably accomplished exactly what he wanted. Which was for the player to experience a vague unclear story for them to try and interpret. The game is pretty much the right length too so it doesn’t overstay it’s welcome or last tooooo short. I still kinda question it’s selling price but…

But anyway. Yeah. Good ♥♥♥♥. Would like to see him continue game development for years to come including after Devestated Dreams.

reviewText:
Very disappointed with never-ending nightmares. The atmospheric build up managed to easily cross the line from a slow burn to intensely boring. I usually have very good patience for walking simulators and non-combat games but this pushed that way too far.

And even when the game does get going, all you have to look forward to are monster encounters that rely on extremely simple stealth mechanics. Then the encounters get harder and harder, as if the developer forgot they weren’t making a Platform game. Nothing kills a horror game faster than obvious game mechanics and dying over and over and over.

Worst of all, there are no new ideas here besides the art-style. Hunted house, creepy asylum, scary little girls. It’s like someone took a book of incredibly lazy horror tropes and made a game out of it. It even has the bald creepy baby heads all over the place, like it copied it’s homework from Alice: Madness Returns.

The story is told just vaguely enough that my curiosity didn’t even kick in. if there’s some twist at the end of this game I can’t be bothered to find out because the rest of it doesn’t drop any clues.

And, Ironically while I did indeed get both of those things I got nothing else. reviewText:
having just had a few moments to start the game my review will be brief. first some disclosure. i did back the game on kickstarter after trying the demo. however i didnt back enough to get alpha/beta acess so im not as spoiled on the game as some others may be. i will say this game isnt for anyone if youre looking for a challenge or even scary monsters or lots of jumpscares. this isnt the game for that. the game is atmospheric  with the audio and visuals presented to you in a way to try to unnerve you. the back grouds becoming worse in their conditions as you progress. some i have seen have complained about the characters movement speed and i know this will sound like a flimsy excuse. but if you stop to think about it. the character is in a nightmare and in nightmares you barely ever move as you would for real. i also dont know about many of you but if im in a strange envrionment where i feel threatend im not going to run like the wind and draw attention if i knock something over. the asthma aspect is something i find intersting and i like theres a limit.  i also find some of the images ive seen on my own playthrough so far and  LPS ive watched make me reach for that body part in sympathy.

now whats not to like about this game? as ive said its not for everyone. like in a nightmare ive seen some places loop for a bit and start to mesh together but i dont think it detracts from the game unless by the time you reach the end of the first part of the asylum youre already bored or frustrated.  which i can see some people being.

second the lack of jumpscares challenges or alot  of monsters. these may be common complaints from players coming into the game looking for something to scare them  most of them having played games like outlast or five nights at freddies or amnesia. honestly those games dont appeal to me where this one did. i like the fact that theres no challenge and instead of being frustrated or being jumpscared or chased for the hundredth time i can get myself immersed in the world the creator made.

all in all i would reccomend giving the game a shot or watching an lp of it i can understand some saying the $15 price tag is a bit much and if youre hesitant wait until a sale. i believe this creator has some potential and would love to see him make one more before passing judgement on his abilities. i see this game as more of a window into the suffering of someone whose had dark thoughts and nightmares and how probably during those times he never felt it would get better.

reviewText:
okay, I'm going to stop screwing around and actually review this because it grabbed my attention and firmly held it in a headlock until completion.

Neverending Nightmares is what would happen if Shel Silverstein and Guillermo Del Toro collaborated on a collection of fairy tales and poems for adults and someone made a game out of it.  This was a wonderful title and it's a great one to start out with if you wanna get into horror gaming.  The storybook illustrations, the tense atmosphere, the gritty and foreboding environments, even some of the enemies you encounter, just. . . everything. . . it's great.  EVEN THE SOUNDTRACK is keeping you on edge with it's whispers and deep tones as you make your way around the twisted dreamscape.  The developers put honest-to-God effort into this and I couldn't be more satisfied.  The price is a bit steep, especially for the short length of it, but if you've got the scratch and are curious enough, BUY IT.

10/10 would wake up in a cold sweat after pulling the vein out of my arm again

reviewText:
Took a bit over an hour to get a first ending, about the same to see the others after that, with level/nightmare select and a guide.

I'm torn about this one.

I love the subject matter, I love that it is a very personnal project. Lots of cool ideas. Love the graphics. The audio is awesome. But I ended up liking the whole a lot less than I hoped I would.

As a game it fails for me. Except jump scares (ok, there's a couple of nice ones) it wasn't scary to me. Creepy? Sure. The audio is the element working best at being oppressive and unnerving. Having no clear goal is a problem, that leaves exploration. But the levels are so empty that it wasn't fulfilling. There are no puzzles per say, you just progress in a rather straight line and double back when you find a dead (no pun intended) end. There are very few interactive elements, and a lot of those a rather bland, like many family portraits that are never of any use or reference to anything as far as I can tell. There are a couple of ennemies to dodge or run from, and if you die to them you'll restart in a nearby bed and do it again, or maybe it'll be one of the few story related ones and it'll make the 'story' 'progress' which inside of a level is basically redoing close to the same thing, but with slightly more messed up decoration and little less light.

I do get the link to depression. Helplessness, repetition, little control over things.. As a statement I can appreciate it. As a game, it is just that: repetition. Maybe having my own battles with depression makes all of this a bit more mundane to me, I don't know.

It is also just too slow for me.. Between wondering what could be the next jump scare and the slooooooooooow walking pace of the character, I found my mind drifting away, bored. Single elements, graphically, are really well done, but with so much repetition in tone, it becomes too samey to be scary to me.

So. Is it good? Not really. Is it bad? Not really, either !! It is a cool thing expressing Matt's experiences, but I don't think it is a great game as is. I do wish for such things to exist, and I did pledge towards Matt's second title's KS (and would again if a 2nd attempt is made). If you're reading this still, you're probably curious and open enough to want to give it a shot, and to such people I would absolutely recommend a try. If you found this almost at random and are looking for a game-game, this is a harder sell to say the least, unless you're really easily unsettled and scared by disturbing imagery.

reviewText: A lot of people think that Kool-Aid Jammers are just for kids, but I disagree. They're my particular favorite when it comes to pouched drinks, on top of others like Capri Sun. While they may not be as healthy as the others (but then, none of them are particularly healthy, really), I've found that Kool-Aid Jammers have a stronger flavor than the other brands, and don't have that watered down feeling that some of the others have. My personal favorite flavor is Cherry, and it's usually the only flavor I buy - there used to be a Cherry Limeade flavor that was better, but they seem to have stopped selling those. Kool-Aid Jammers might not be the best drink you could get, but they're good, fast drinks for when you want something with a stronger taste than water but want something more hydrating than a soda, with the convenience of a pouch meaning you don't have to take a lot of time away from your game to grab one.\n\nThe reason I'm talking about Kool-Aid Jammers instead of Neverending Nightmares is two-fold; not only did my Kool-Aid Jammer outlast the game, but I also found it more interesting. Nevending Nightmares is a game that puts up a nice face in terms of atmosphere and art and sound design, but quickly falls apart when you actually play it. The game is, as the title implies, about a character experiencing neverending nightmares. You wake up in your bed, walk through one of three environments, and at the end something kills you and you wake up in the next nightmare. This goes on for about one hour (for a game called Neverending Nightmares, it sure does end pretty quickly), and then the game ends. Every now and then it'll bring in mechanics familiar to horror game fans, like a monster that you have to hide in a closet to avoid or an enemy that you can't sprint by, but these are few and far between and the enemies are so basic that it doesn't even feel like an effort to avoid them, let alone anything that might make you feel nervous around them. The only reason I even know what they do when they catch you is because each of them do it at least once in the scripted next-level death. The art style is unique, and the audio is well-designed to boost the atmosphere (though the special headphones" sound option it encourages you to use seemed more like it was meant for bad headphones than ones more suited for gaming

reviewText:
This game is short, but it has greater impact than many other horror and scare games that last much longer.  Neverending Nightmares grabs you right from the beginning: there is no tutorial that overstays its welcome; a control guide; or even an hour-long opening sequence before you dive in.  Instead, the game begins immediately, and without any GUI to distance you from the action, you being your neverending nightmare...

The graphics and atmosphere are very unique, and the hand-drawn nature of the game really helps establish a surreal setting that only increases in horror and intrigue as you progress.  The audio is integral to the experience, and pulls you in even further to this cacophony of mind-bending, psychological distortion of an adventure.

Having said that, the length is bad not because it's too short, but that it feels like there's so much more story and setting to explore.  The game doesn't overstay its welcome, but it doesn't really stay for dinner either.

reviewText: I backed Neverending Nightmares on Kickstarter because I like its black-and-white Edward Gorey style & because of its OCD & self-harm themes.  Players walk the labyrinthine halls & rooms of a decaying house. What are you looking for? How do you get out? It's not clear. The house alters each time you traverse it. A dead-end path now opens onto hallways. Nothing is stable. Nothing is trustworthy. The game repeats environmental elements to inspire OCD thought patterns. Did you try that door already? Better try it again. Each successive nightmare journey through the house reveals more of the PC's story—and more of his psychological landscape. Play it at night with the headphones on & you'll get the shivers.  I personally find this game scarier than the PT demo.\n

reviewText: This game had a lot of things about it which I thought were very good but I can't bring myself to recommend it as over all it was rather boring. The art style is nice with the dark, detailed, hand drawn style but the over use of bright red blood negated the impact for me as it made it seem overly childish. The music and sound effects are excellent especially they way the sound effect subtly herald the approach of an enemy. The music together with the visuals create a great atmosphere that reminded me of the good silent hill games in places. The story is disappointing it starts of with mysterious hints as to what is going on but never really develops. I suppose they had to keep it vague to get it to fit in with each of the different endings but it just felt like it was going nowhere then suddenly an ending happened. The main problem is that this game mostly involves slowly walking through very similar corridors until something happens causing you to wake up and repeat the process. howlongtobeat.com suggested this game would take 1.5 – 2 hours to complete so I started this game with the intention of playing the whole game in one session but after an hour or so I was too bored to carry on. On another occasion after dying and waking up I took a wrong turn and inadvertently started heading off in the wrong direction, because the levels are so repetitive I did not realise this until I had got all the way back to the very beginning of the section. I guess the repeated similar environments were supposed to give the impression of being trapped and heighten the sense of horror but in the end it was just boring.

reviewText: I really wanted to like this game. I really did. And I tried my best to fully immerse myself in its dark atmosphere, playing with headphones, taking it slowly and all. It worked well for a few minutes, but then...the game ended. After less than two hours, it was over. And the ending was abrupt, weak and somewhat inconsistent. There are multiple endings, yes, but they are simply determined by which path you (blindly) choose in the last few sections, there are no big puzzles or significant choices to make during the course of the game. And seeing all of the three endings doesn't really make things better. They make everything confusing and nonsensical at first, they become clearer after putting a bit of thought into them, but still you are left with a sense of something missing.\n\nNeverending Nightmares is not an awful experience to endure, on the contrary it is filled with undeniable inspiration, but as it is it's a totally rushed and incomplete work. And that saddens me a lot, because it's a terrible waste to see a title with such a beautiful, deeply unsetting visual design and so much narrative potential fail to deliver something up to the expectations. It would have taken so little to make this game really beautiful and worth playing that I really cannot condone the way it's been presented. And it's just a terrible pity. I'm giving my thumb down with the highest reclutance this time, but I have to.

reviewText: Neverending Nightmares isn't your typical horror game. It doesn't rely on jumpscares or even the fear of a jumpscare; instead it build's a creepy and disturbing atmosphere through sound design and the effective shaded 2D art-style, which makes blood really stand out. The game follows Thomas, a man seemly stuck in a world of his own making and your task is to somehow escape. The game plays off imagery of depression and suicide to build a world where we, as the player, are not only afraid but also sympathise with Thomas' plight. The story thread about Gabby is contradictory and often leaves you wondering who this women/girl actually is, with different areas of the game offering different explaination.\n\nMy one complaint is that a lot of the same enemies and enviroments are used far too often and the game is FAR too short (i completed the beta in about an hour). But I would still recommend for horror fans!

reviewText:
This game is really good but unfortunately, $13.50 SGD of price makes me wonder if it is justified. I finished the game as well as to find all the endings, all in 3 hours (It was meant to be 2 on mine but it was actually 3 hours because I started from the middle of the game itself sometimes). Would I recommend it? With some hesistation, yes. Wait for a discount would be better.

Nevertheless, the game brings out a different horror genre itself. Other games scares you with well planned jump scares. This game however, makes you uncomfortable to the core and adds mental stress to you at times, which should be a psychological horror genre game. The atmosphere can be pretty scary and freaky too.

The art style of this game is inspired/ originated from Edward Gorey, which gives a distinct style as if everything is drawn out with ink. The intensity of black horizontal lines are the marks of bright and dark areas. The game has only black and white unless there are objects that you can interact with or there is blood (red).

The level design is great and because of the art and colour style, the players do understand what can be interacted without the help of a tutorial though the enemies do take time to figure about on how to avoid them.

The sounds are really aiding with the atmosphere as well. It's distorted, the music is weird and is out of place and makes you more uncomfortable. If you play the game, be sure to wear a headphone. They have made it so that the experience is more immerse with headphones.

This game is an unforgettable experience and I would give it 3.8/5

reviewText:
This is an interesting game in that it's not as much about the story, or even the abject horror, as it is about conveying certain emotions.  Matt Gilgenbach, the creator of Neverending Nightmares, suffers from depression and OCD, and this game exists to help convey what that is like.  The player will experience anxiety, dread, and general discomfort.  Of course that is because there are jump scares and monsters that are trying to kill him, but the point is the feelings that are transmitted.  The visuals are inspired by Edward Gorey, and of course incredibly disturbing, and the sound will keep the player on edge at all times, especially with headphones.

Neverending Nightmares does have a story, but it's disjointed and intentionally vague.  There are three endings, but none of them are canon.  You can try to put the pieces together to create a cohesive whole, but it's like having 450 pieces of a 500-piece jigsaw puzzle. Connections can be made, but you won't necessarily get the whole picture, and that's the point.  Clinical depression is not a rational thing.  There is not always a reason for people to feel depressed, except that their brains tell them so.  Be aware of this when you are trying to interpret the story.

The game is also heavy on symbolism, from the enemies to dream tropes that are lying around, like blood, teeth, and even the player's own slow running speed.  While the entire game, if you go for all of the endings and branching paths, will probably end up taking less than 2.5 hours, I would still argue that it is worth the purchase for the unique experience it provides, as well as for its part in helping spread awareness of OCD and clinical depression.  This game is great, and I highly recommend it.

reviewText: Neverending Nightmares is a horror adventure game thats 2D and all hand drawn but will you want to play it ? In Neverending Nightmares you play as Thomas who is unable to wake up from nightmares. Everything leads into a new nightmare.So how is this game ? Its quite good honestly. The game was made by a person who suffered from mental illness. So ill try to explain how the game is played. Neverending Nightmares is also quite pretty to look at and it really has outstanding sound effects too, i highly suggest you play in the dark with headphones. Overall Nevenending nightmares is an excellent horror game for fans of the genre and i suggest everyone to pick this game up just to see how awfull it is to have a nightmare let alone never to wake up from one. I give Neverending Nightmares a 7.5/10

reviewText:
I must admit it took me some time on deciding if I would reccomend this game or not but the crucial question to ask yourself is how much are you willing to pay for something a little different.

THE GOOD
You should know that this game is certainly not  a must play" but I do give credit where credit is due. The penciled in artstyle with highlights of color is certainly interesting and is something I really enjoyed seeing compared to so many dull
recommended:
3D horror games. The images in the backgrounds are also very well done with plenty of both overtly horrific images as well as many subtly disturbing images. There are also a few jump scares sprinkled throughout for good measure but they are spaced far enough apart that they dont become tedious. I should also mention the sound design is really quite supurb. When using headphones you can hear plenty of slight noises such as whispers or footsteps that increase the dramatic tension. Last of all the price is fairly reasonable. I was able to buy this game during a winter sale for $6.75 USD which is less than I've paid for much worse games.

THE BAD
The biggest complaint you will find from myself and others is the lack of player agency (walking simulator is in the tags for a good reason). The actual gameplay largely consists of only walking forward and avoiding enemies and even when avoiding enemies it's a simplistic affair as you will likely only die a couple of times before recognizing a pattern in the enemy behavior. Another major issue is that the game manages to be both short (about 2 hours for 100 percent completion) and yet tedious. You'll see many recycled hallways that you'll have to run through with the shortest invisible stamina bar in the world. While this repetitive nature does help the game feel more like an actual nightmare that you cannot escape from it does lose its charm fairly quickly.

CONCLUSION
If you have a few extra dollars in your steam wallet and want to try a different but short horror game give Neverending Nightmares a try! For anyone that is looking to get the best for their money this one may be worth a pass."

reviewText:
This is a wonderful and eerie game.
Its art style is thoughtfully curated, and reminiscent of Edward Gorey macabre illustrations.

It's not a game about fighting, or running away from enemies, but one about an increasing sense of discomfort and tension. A deep sensation of wrongness ebbs from it, while you play, thanks to the maze of similar rooms creating confusion and preventing you from ever feel safe, and the masterfully crafted sound effects and music accompanying your actions.

The most important aspects of this game are its atmosphere and its tone, and those are certainly excellent.

If you let yourself immerse in this weird unsettling world of nightmares and weird dreams you are going to love it.

reviewText:
I am rather torn whether to recommend this game or not... There is some really nice ideas here and the art style is great. That said it is short (not a bad thing really), but the game has three ending paths with choices at the end of two chapters to decide the ending. So to see all the content you have to replay the same chapters and make the choice at the end to see the additional ten minutes of content.

Pros:

- Some effective jump scares
- Wonderful art style.
- Lots of wonderful creepy imagery
- An interesting horror story which did not over stay its welcome.

Cons:

- Backtracking.... To see all endings you have to replay about 20 to 30 minutes of content. This is simply the biggest issue with the game.
- Monsters/puzzles are all extremely easy. You see a cupboard then there is a good chance a monster will be in the hall and you will avoid it by hiding in the cupboard... The monsters in the Insanity level I thought were just desturbing imagery until the end of the chapter one kills me and it turned out they had just been easy to avoid up until that point.
- Very linear game play apart from the 3 endings. This makes back tracking frustratingly dull.
- Yes porcelain dolls are creepy, but are heavily overused to the point it just becomes funny.


Overall, this was a unique game and I did generally enjoy the game. It is just a shame that back tracking is such a pain to view all content. The game has flaws but care and time went into making an interesting horror game experience. Therefore, if you enjoy horror games or if you enjoy games that use an interesting art style its worth giving the game a go.

reviewText:
Neverending Nightmares is a short little game, but I would definitely recommend that any horror fan take the time to play through it. The one thing that I would strongly caution people of, is that there are parts of the game that are deeply unsettling particularly to anyone dealing with depression or self-harm issues, as some of the cutscenes and visuals strike pretty close to home in those areas. That being said, it's worth taking the time for.

The storyline is good, a simple premise that is told in an interesting way, while being relatively easy to follow. The cutscenes are informative, but not overly long and they don't distract the player from the game too much.

The gameplay itself is simple, and therefore easy enough to pick up, meaning you can jump right into the game itself without any lengthy tuturials, which is great. There aren't very many controls as the actions of your character are limited, but this simply fuels your desire not to run into any enemies, which is good since you really have no way to combat them. I tend to find that in horror titles, enemies that you can't fight have a higher psychological toll on the player and are therefore more effective generally speaking.

The thing that I love most about this game is the artwork. The visual style of the game is incredibly unique and despite not being a terrifying style in and of itself, it's used in a way that adds to the atmosphere very well. The predominantly black and white color scheme is accented perfectly with just the items of importance being colored, which is a nice way to guide the player through the game without specifically telling them what to do. It also makes for some of the most visually appealing blood I've ever seen in a video game, just because the red on the black and white makes such a shark contrast.

The one issue that I really had with the game was how slow the gameplay was in certain areas. As someone that doesn't have the best sense of direction, I had a tough time through some of the levels in regards to knowing where to go. I couldn't remember where I had been which made knowing which way to go difficult, and it became a bit tedious trying to figure it out when the character moves so slowly (though the slow movement speed does add suspense in a few places.) I also became annoyed only being able to use the run function for short distances, but it was a minor inconvenience.

All in all, I would rate this game very highly and would feel good suggesting it to just about anyone.

reviewText:
Quite simply put, this game excells in its atmosphere and in terms of subtlety, an aspect that is lacking in most games nowadays, especially horror titles. There is very little jump scares involved in the game and the few that are involved in ways that fit the atmosphere of the game. The imagery is frightening (and gets pretty disturbing at points), the subject matter gets incredibly dark, the audio presentation is amazing, and the story manages to be abstracxt enough to get your own interpretation, yet clear enough so that you can be entertained by what you are seeing. It is a game that rewards thought, which is a rare aspect of stories in games.

There are only a few complaints I have, the first being that, while the art style is well drawn and adds to the atmosphere, I found there to be a slight bit of eye strain due to the amounts of small lines of various different monochrome shades that represent the darkness, which tends to just look incredibly awful in motion, which is even worse due to the flickering when the screen moves, so you may want to pass on this if you have especially sensitive eyes.

The other being that the game is kind of simplistic gameplay wise, and you spend most of the time just walking left or right, while occasionally trying to figure out how to slip by an enemy, which is in a rather simplistic way each time. The game is also light on content and can be beaten in about 4 hours, although it can be a bit longer if you take your time. Overall though, I highly reccomend this game. It really knows how to handle horror and atmosphere incredibly well and is one of the most underrated games of 2014.

reviewText:
Overall I was quite pleased with this game. It's very atmospheric and kind of disturbing. I didn't find it scary, but I don't think a lot of games are. It captures the feeling of wandering through a nightmare where you are unable to exert any control, you just have to stay on the move. However, it does have some flaws. I found that the game didn't successfully keep me in a state of immersion, so a lot of my complaints would be nitpicky for any other genre, but I think that with horror it's really important to keep the player from thinking about how they're playing a game.

The Gorey-esque line drawings are great and I liked the effects when you move into lighter and darker areas. However, you can see the seams of the 3D-looking-2D effect often enough to be jarring (the straightjacket guys turning their heads, for example.)

There's not really a lot of game here (that's not bad necessarily, there's nothing wrong with being an interactive experience) and I was sort of expecting more puzzles, especially with all the flavor stuff to look at. At first I was trying to examine every piece of furniture and object in the house and I was actually a little disappointed to realize that only things in color were interactive. Having such an obvious tell made it seem less immersive. Also, it seems like they front-loaded all the non-plot related weird stuff to look at, because there were quite a few hotspots with nightmare stuff in the first area and then nothing for the rest of the game.

I found myself getting frustrated with the slow pace, especially on replays trying to open different paths. I tend to play for long sessions and unable to not do that, and I think this game would be better parceled out gradually. There's not a lot of game here, I got it on sale but at full price it seems like a lot. I have one more achievment to get, by the time I 100% the game I'll probably have spent less than 3 hours on it. I could see myself having the desire to periodically revisit the game, though.

reviewText:
I am rather torn whether to recommend this game or not... There is some really nice ideas here and the art style is great. That said it is short (not a bad thing really), but the game has three ending paths with choices at the end of two chapters to decide the ending. So to see all the content you have to replay the same chapters and make the choice at the end to see the additional ten minutes of content.

Pros:

- Some effective jump scares
- Wonderful art style.
- Lots of wonderful creepy imagery
- An interesting horror story which did not over stay its welcome.

Cons:

- Backtracking.... To see all endings you have to replay about 20 to 30 minutes of content. This is simply the biggest issue with the game.
- Monsters/puzzles are all extremely easy. You see a cupboard then there is a good chance a monster will be in the hall and you will avoid it by hiding in the cupboard... The monsters in the Insanity level I thought were just desturbing imagery until the end of the chapter one kills me and it turned out they had just been easy to avoid up until that point.
- Very linear game play apart from the 3 endings. This makes back tracking frustratingly dull.
- Yes porcelain dolls are creepy, but are heavily overused to the point it just becomes funny.


Overall, this was a unique game and I did generally enjoy the game. It is just a shame that back tracking is such a pain to view all content. The game has flaws but care and time went into making an interesting horror game experience. Therefore, if you enjoy horror games or if you enjoy games that use an interesting art style its worth giving the game a go.
