reviewText:
Like the creator, I also suffer from both depression and O.C.D, so before the game came out I wondered how it could possibly depict what it's like to suffer from these illnesses, especially O.C.D. as it isn't an illness that I could imagine working well within a game. However, having now played the game, I actually think it does a really good job of showing the kind of mindset people who suffer from these kinds of illnesses experience.
Not only do I think the game does a good job of showing what it's like inside the mind of people who suffer from these illnesses, but I also think it does a good job as a horror game in its own right. Whilst some of the more frigtening moments are just jump scares, it does very well to create a very creepy environment that really made me feel like I had to escape.
I also liked the cool, hand-drawn art style. Being creepy, yet simplistic, it manages to fit in well with the eerie World in the game, whilst at the same time fitting in with the underlying tone of the game, that is trying to get across what it's like to suffer from depression and O.C.D. as suffering from O.C.D. often makes simple tasks a source of great distress and anxiety, which the art style seems to be a metaphor for.
To summarise, whether you just like horror games, or whether you're interested in getting an insight into what it's like to suffer from one or more mental illnesses, Neverending Nightmares is a game I'd recommend.

All in all, I think this game is a good starting point if you want to get into horror games. I mean that as a compliment.

I wouldn't say that this game is necessarily bad. It's got a pretty good atmosphere and decent jumpscares. The artwork's great (they even make it easy to spot landmarks so that you don't get lost, even though pretty much everything's in black and white), and the voice acting is pretty good, as well. Each section of the game pretty much has its own unique set of monsters with the exception of one or two, and that gives a pretty good variety. It's short enough to show a friend to just play through really quickly - I got all of the paths in 3 hours.

A lot of the time, I wasn't really that scared, which is sort of bad news for a horror game. While the atmosphere is pretty scary at first, it sort of fades once you actually get to see each of the monsters - the mystery sort of disappears, and it's really easy to learn how to deal with them pretty quickly. I think the main problem with this game is that it's just a ton of walking with only a small handful of scattered monsters or jumpscares in relatively few places. I don't want to make a joke like Walking Simulator 2015" or anything like that

reviewText:
At first it seems like it takes after Lone Survivor,  but Neverending Nightmares has more in common with Dear Esther.  There's very little gaming to do.  All you do is march down long hallways, listen to the moody music, look at the creepy imagery, and eventually you get to the end.  Some may even compare it to Amnesia: The Dark Descent, but that game had plenty of things for the player to do.  It wasn't just a forced march down dark hallways; you had goals, and the monsters were actively chasing you!

Having little to do gamewise isn't necessarily a bad thing.  To The Moon was very much like this, but what set that game apart from this one is the story.  To The Moon, Lone Survivor, and Amnesia all have a complete story to uncover at the end.  Neverending Nightmares does not.  It leaves you with a bunch of confusing pieces of a story with no resolution--yet another game that thinks being vague is the same as being profound.  (I'm looking at you, Braid!)

All you do is march down long hallways, open doors, march down more long hallways, and at the end of the march is a jump-scare.  These jump-scares are effective, but after the fourth time, it becomes routine.  Oh yes, and dolls are creepy.  We get it.  Dolls *are* creepy.

Neverending Nightmares feels like it was built around its soundtrack.  The levels are ridiculously long just to make you absorb the music.  The ambient horror music makes this game, and it does a very good job creating atmosphere.  The art style is especially memorable.  I've never seen a game look like this, and it adds a lot to the creep factor.

Steam won't let me give this a neutral rating, but it deserves one.  I didn't hate this game, as it did a very good job creating atmosphere and jump-scaring me more than once, but I found the delivery more tedious than scary, and the 3 payoffs at the end do not provide a satisfying resolution to all that marching.

reviewText:
I must admit it took me some time on deciding if I would reccomend this game or not but the crucial question to ask yourself is how much are you willing to pay for something a little different.

THE GOOD
You should know that this game is certainly not  a must play" but I do give credit where credit is due. The penciled in artstyle with highlights of color is certainly interesting and is something I really enjoyed seeing compared to so many dull
recommended:
3D horror games. The images in the backgrounds are also very well done with plenty of both overtly horrific images as well as many subtly disturbing images. There are also a few jump scares sprinkled throughout for good measure but they are spaced far enough apart that they dont become tedious. I should also mention the sound design is really quite supurb. When using headphones you can hear plenty of slight noises such as whispers or footsteps that increase the dramatic tension. Last of all the price is fairly reasonable. I was able to buy this game during a winter sale for $6.75 USD which is less than I've paid for much worse games.

THE BAD
The biggest complaint you will find from myself and others is the lack of player agency (walking simulator is in the tags for a good reason). The actual gameplay largely consists of only walking forward and avoiding enemies and even when avoiding enemies it's a simplistic affair as you will likely only die a couple of times before recognizing a pattern in the enemy behavior. Another major issue is that the game manages to be both short (about 2 hours for 100 percent completion) and yet tedious. You'll see many recycled hallways that you'll have to run through with the shortest invisible stamina bar in the world. While this repetitive nature does help the game feel more like an actual nightmare that you cannot escape from it does lose its charm fairly quickly.

CONCLUSION
If you have a few extra dollars in your steam wallet and want to try a different but short horror game give Neverending Nightmares a try! For anyone that is looking to get the best for their money this one may be worth a pass."

reviewText:
I just found one of the 3 endings of Neverending Nightmares (in 1.4 hours). This intrigues me for the replayablity factor that is presented,  however the thought of trudging (and I use that word literally to describe the speed at which the asthmatic main character moves) through labyrinthine corridors deters me from pursuing them for the time being. Even if I were to find all 3 endings, I'm not sure I'd ever revisit this title though. There are some games I do revisit from time to time, this is unfortunately not going to be one of those titles. I'd say the current 68/100 metacritic score is accurate.

What the game does well:
The atmosphere is done well, and I particularly enjoyed the Edward Gorey aesthetic used in the design, as well as the use of color to draw attention to specifc details. The few frights and encounters kept things interesting, as well did the atmospheric music (definitely play with headphones).
The running is short-lived and easily expired, which presents the user with choices to make especially when present in more dangerous situations.
Non-reliant on Jump scares:  Neverending Nightmare might have a few tricks of its own in the jump department, but its focus on the environment and sound are its strong points.

What could be improved:
The Pacing - The character speed could probably be sped up about 1.5 to 2 times their current speed with as much walking around is required. I'd liken the current speed to that of wading through knee deep water,,, for the entire game.
If you want to make a character move that slow, then the atmosphere needs to be more engaging (whether that be more benign haunts, more background detail to focus on, or slow changes to environment as the character moves though it). Neverending Nightmares does provide all of these, however it feels as though it's not quite enough as you slowly  navigate its corridors.
Considering I found one ending in 1.4 hours, you could argue the speed is artificially extending the play time.
The Ending(s) - I've only seen one ending so far. It was more like a quick scene rather than a fleshed out closure, so the payout felt a bit weak considering the narrative through scenery the game otherwise provides.

Who I would recommend this to:
One of my friends got bored, maybe getting past the first nightmare only and then moving on. However, they tend to be more action oriented rather than savoring that slow build-up.
If you enjoy games that focus heavily on exploration (wander quests" as I call them) and enjoy a slower pace in a dark room

reviewText:
(**This is a pretty neutral review, but Steam reviews don't leave that much room for nuance**)

**Here's a quick TL,DR: A unique and interesting horror/adventure hybrid, that lets itself down and falls a bit flat, but does still do just enough to stand on its own.**

Oh Neverending Nightmares, you stood on the precipice of greatness, but then you made a few mistakes, and those misteps drove you down a considerable ammount. As it stands, rather than setting the world on fire and becoming a revolutionary classic, you're an above average, competently executed horror/adventure hybrid.

Before we get to why this game falls short, let's take a moment to acknowledge all the things it does right. First off, it is creepy and unnerving throughout. The atmosphere is incredible. This is accomplished by a beautiful, unique, and simple (yet also nicely detailed) art style. The detailed closeups of items scattered throughout the world are a very nice touch, and do a lot to help flesh out the world. Backing that up is some of the best sound design I've ever encountered in a horror game. No exageration, it sounds every bit as creepy as you could want. Not wanting to spoil anything, the third section of the game made me so genuinely uncomfortable because of the sound design, that I actually had to walk away from the game for a little bit.

Beyond atmosphere, I want to commend the game's designer for being so openly influenced by mental illness. I don't have much to say about that right now, but that took guts, so, well done. Knowing this information going in helps significantly appreciate a lot of design choices.

Finally, in addition to the atmosphere, the level design is great itself. While only existing of pretty straight forward hallways and paths, the world itself gets a lot of distance out of this simplicity, even as the vast majority of movement occurs on a 2D plane. The paths you can take branch out, twist around themselves, and generally seem to shift around you. It's honestly creepy, and unnerving as you try to make sense out of the impossible geometries the game builds and lets you explore.

It's worth noting that this game is not particurally long. As many people have pointed out, it only takes about an hour or two to finish a playthrough. However, I won't hold this against the game too much, as its length feels appropriate. It does what it wants to do, and then ends without overstaying its welcome. And yes, $15 dollars for 1 hour of play is a bit steep in comparison to a lot of games, but the budget conscious among us could always wait for a sale to save a few dollars. It's worth noting that despite the cost and relatively short length, I didn't feel ripped off or cheated out of my money.

So now, we come inevitably to the part where I need to break out the criticisms. First off, and this is the most minor of my criticisms, as big as the game world appears to be, it seems to consist of a lot of empty space. There are plenty of uninteresting dead ends, as well as some repeating elements that start to lose luster very quickly.

Next up, and more damaging to the game overall, is the enemy design. The game starts out with positive points in this category because you've got absolutely no offensive capabilties, and no defensive capabilities beyond running away, and even that can only be done for short distances. These facts make enemies legitimate threats, and keeps this from approaching anything actiony, and keeps you feeling disempowered and helpless, the key elements of horror. However, from this strong start, the game quickly surrenders the advantage.  There are a very small number of enemy types throughout the game. While this isn't the end of the world, the enemies are largely uninspired. They are mostly humanoid, not truly anything too horrifying or mostrous. But again, this could be overlooked, or may even be something some people like. But what ultimately is the final nail in the coffin on this issue, is that dealing with the enemies is just dull. They are mostly just tests of patience, more than anything intrinsically interesting to encounter or deal with. They are easy to figure out how to deal with, and once you accomplish that, they do little more than add arbitrary wait times to each encounter. There are a few puzzles which use the enemy mechanics to interesting effect, but to be honest, other than serving as the essential threat to life itself, the enemies serve little purpose. In a game with as great an atmosphere and understanding of pacing and discomfort, it's practically criminal that the enemies are so weakly designed.

And finally, my biggest criticism of the game comes up. This has to do with the structure of the story. I'm going to try to avoid all spoilers about specific events and occurances of the story, but I will be talking about narative structure here. The important thing to know is that the game has multiple endings based on which paths you take throughout the game. These are mostly subtle choices, that honestly you won't notice until you get told by the game where the choices were at the end. Having multiple endings is the greatest flaw of this game, despite how well they are integrated into the gameplay. To explain why, you need to understand that the game is drenched in symbolism, from small details of the environment, to enemy design and even gameplay mechanics. But by having three separate endings, the developer essentially rendered two-thirds of the symbols encountered in a given playthrough completely moot and meaningless. While having the multiple paths does pad out the length of the game, as you backtrack to find all the divergent paths, I'd rather have one very solid ending than three weak-ish endings. The only real defense that I can think of for this is that having multiple endings contributes to the themes of ambiguity throughout the game, but this is a pretty weak justification. These endings are also mostly cliched, and not particularly exciting, especially when contrasted with the incredible atmosphere on display.

So, if the game is short, has weak enemy design, has an ultimately dissappointing story, and generally has weak gameplay, why is there a big thumbs up next to this review? Well, for all of the criticisms I can fairly levy against this game, as I said, I never felt ripped off by this game. I was engaged for as long as I played it, and even the ending, while abrupt and weak, wasn't a deal breaker by any means. It also is one of the few games I've found that describes itself as psychological horror, and does enough to earn that title. While there are a few jump scares, they are used sparingly enough as to not weaken the game, and the rest of the game puts you in a disempowered place and truly messes with you, leaving a lingering sense of fear and unease. If you're a fan of real horror, and not the empty meaningless YouTube-bait horror with exclusively meaningless jumpscares, definately give this game a shot.

reviewText:
Neverending Nightmares offers a breath of fresh air in a genre dominated by experiences like Slender: The Arrival and Amnesia: The Dark Descent.  This side-scrolling game combines hand-drawn aesthetics, unsettling atmosphere, and sparse but terrifying jump scares.

One of my few issues with Neverending Nightmares arises in what I consider to be lazy storytelling. Although I enjoy abstract and cryptic plot-lines, I couldn't remember the name of the hero's sister after finishing my first playthrough.  Considering that Thomas and Gabby are the only two characters in the game, you would hope I'd be able to tell you a bit more about them than I actually can.  (I know they're siblings, and I know Thomas is older than her, but that's pretty much it.)  Secondly, the story occasionally sacrifices depth for shallow creepiness.  Sure, I thought the lecture in the asylum was creepy—but did it reveal anything about the protagonist?  Not really.  That said, the story does have one thing in its favor: multiple endings establish this game as one with high replayability.

Secondly, even though Infinitap Games claims Neverending Nightmares seeks to promote a greater understanding of mental illness
date:
I rarely felt as though the game actually discussed this.  While one of the endings delves into this theme, it is easy to miss if you play without first reading up on the backstory behind Neverending Nightmares. The goal was commendable; it's too bad the implementation wasn't there.

My complaints, though valid, pale in comparison to the many positive qualities of Neverending Nightmares.  Some people might be concerned about the simplistic gameplay—over a period of two to four hours (depending whether or not you choose to find all the endings), you will do nothing but walk, run, and interact with maybe a dozen objects.  I admit this sounds tedious, but in reality the game's simplicity results in a sort of streamlined horror:my limited options heightened the tension because I knew I would be unable to hide or fight back.

Not that the tension needs heightening.  This game possesses an incredible atmosphere, dark and dense and forbidding. The atmospheric tension starts with a unique art style: the black and white dichotomy creates a sparseness that elevates the few colors in Neverending Nightmares.  My pulse spiked whenever I saw the vivid redness of blood, and I grew paranoid when I discovered a yellow candle.  An under-appreciated aspect of the art lies in its incorporation of shadow.  Dynamic shadows based on light sources swerve and flicker around Thomas, and thin lines of blackness darken rooms.

Of course no creepy atmosphere would be complete without audio, and I'm happy to say that both the music and the sound design are well done.  One of the Kickstarter rewards for Neverending Nightmares allowed backers to create a sound that would appear in game, and the variety of these sounds helps make this experience even more nerve-wracking.  Additionally, all of the audio is specially crafted for headphones.  The way certain sounds only register in one ear or the other kept convincing me that there was someone behind me.

While the jump scares don't quite match up to the superb atmosphere, they still frightened me.  Some of these scares are traditional: expect to be chased by several humanoid monsters.  That said, there are plenty of unexpected surprises as well.  I won't mention them here, but rest assured that you will be jumping at many different moments.  (Now that I think about it, I guess you shouldn't rest assured.)

Ultimately, Neverending Nightmares is horror with a message.  If you are willing to spend fifteen dollars on a two to four hour game, you'll discover a beautiful, terrifying experience.  Like me, you may be left wanting to know more about Thomas and Gabby...but nonetheless, I recommend fans of the horror genre pick up this indie title.

FINAL SCORE: 8.7/10

This review was written for Literary Video Games. To see the original, click the link below:
http://www.literaryvideogames.com/2014/10/neverending-nightmares-terror-with.html

reviewText: Neverending Nightmares is more about atmosphere than about a coherent point, sadly. The atmosphere is creepy and at times, sorrowful, and it will stay with you. The graphic style is something you'll either love or hate, but it evokes that sense of terror that many of the early horror movies did, if you can grasp how a black and white movie can be terrifying (some cannot). No glitches. No bugs. I have to take some points off for the fact that the storyline doesn't lead anywhere. To make something really hit home, you have to be definite. Neverending Nightmares sketches out possibilities, but never concludes (and the ending is truly a let down). With all that said, you might wonder how this gets a thumbs up. Simple: I got it on sale and I'm a sucker for atmosphere. Still, it's a 6/10 when it could have been an 8.

reviewText:
First things first: Why does Thomas run SO SLOW? He runs short of breath with a 5 second sprint. I know there isn't much chasing in this game, but how slow the protagonist really frustrated me, especially in my second play through. I have asthma irl and even I don't wheeze like that after a few seconds of casual jogging.

I am on the fence about recommending this game. For the original price of $15, I'd say wait for a sale. It's a well done game as far as atmosphere and music. I really like how they adapt the sounds for headphone wears.

I like the style of the art, even if the blood effects look way too red and cheap - like they were pasted on after the fact. The story... well- I played through two endings so far. I like it, and I like how you can try to piece things together yourself. However the game feels much too repetitive.  I would of liked a lot more interactions with items in rooms. Most rooms were empty and dead ends, with simply nothing to do in them.

The style is great, like I said. It's unique and we all need more Devs that explore different styles. For me though, the game doesn't draw me in. I wanted more from this game, but it just feels unfinished over all.

I would still recommend it to other fans of the horror genre, especially those starved for something different than the usual FPS/crafting survival/zombie etc etc game.

reviewText: Initially, I didn't want to recomend this game. The gameplay is essentially a two hour arcade minigame from an old Sierra adventure game, and is incredibly frustrating. The motifs are relatively tries and repetitive. And it has the problem that alot of brawlers have, of a 2d character on a 3d plane. But, something rather interesting happened when I finished the game last night. This morning as I type out my review, I am incredibly tired, for all last night, my dreams were all night terrors. Everytime I blink, I see the world in cross hatch. And this kind of immersion I hacen't expererienced since I first played and saw Pyramid Head staring at me from behind red bars. And that was when I was seven. There is actually a bit towards the end of  the game that is an obvious rip off of Silent Hill 2. This game is described as an experience of a life with ocd, but feel this description could apply to any mental disease. Actually, I think the best way to describe it, is as a nightmare Eric Chahi might have after watching a box set of Vincent Price films. In the end I'd recomend this game to three types of people; anyone who'd like to understand what it is to be mentally, anyone who never got the chance to play PT before it was removed from the PSN, or anyone whose a fan of excellent atmosphere. It's a little bit Edgar Allen Poe, and a little bit of Clocktower, and a little bit of B-Movie gore, and a lot lot lot (that's three lots) of Silent Hill. Without meaning to spoil anything, the ending is frustrating, and doesn't offer any closure, but it isn't a deal breaker. Oh, and don't tell me it's open to interpretation. Blade Runner is open to interpretation because I know what I'm supposed to be interpreting.

reviewText:
TL:DR: this game is an expensive flash game

The game has an interesting concept, but fails to make any relevant progress. It tries to become a survival horror, but takes shortcuts that make it feel more like a flash game than a full product. The best comparison is with P.T. which uses a similar idea: revisiting the same small area with minor changes at every iteration. Unfortunately, the game has you go into several rooms with no real progression. Each time you make a startling discovery or die, and end up in your bed. but the time to reach that climax is slow, stagnant, with an abrupt change. It lacks crescendo. There is a bare-bones stealth area where you hide in a closet while a grotesque baby-faced grunt shakes it. This mechanic is poorly developed, as you only have two directions to flee, and it is a matter of waiting until they are off-screen.

I played one session and did not return, because only 1/5 of the game is actually content, and relies heavily on jump scares and exploration of mostly static environments. Items that you do examine are paintings with no interest or plot progression, as if they were added for either showing off artistic skills or lengthening gameplay.

reviewText:
Neverending Nightmares know what its name stands for: a neverending nightmare.

In a nutshell, you just walk around, occasionally running from some enemy, in a f*cked up scenario.

How would I rate it? A 5/10. Why? Alright, here it goes:

Visuals are amazing. The game's artstyle is really interesting and, while most of the time you're basically walking around the same couple rooms with little difference from eachother, the artstyle makes sure it's a creepy, disturbing and often sick world you're thrown in.

The sounds are really good, the soundtrack is really atmospheric and there is one track in particular when you're reaching the end of the game that is REALLY creepy. Even the voice acting is good, not amazing, but good.

The story and the gameplay is where it falls. Storywise, you're thrown in a world in search for something, something that you really have no idea what will be. You just walk around and see things popping up, trying to make some sense of what's going on. However, the game itself gives you three endings, each one completely different from the other, so you just choose which one you liked the most and there goes your story. Maybe I overlooked it? Alright, but the gameplay made me do it, because they didn't even throw in any puzzle to make you feel like you're actually playing something. Hell, even point-and-click games feel more gamey" than this almost senseless walking thing.

THE VERDICT: Beautifully atmospheric

reviewText:
A dreamlike exploration of living with mental illness, Neverending Nightmares gets a lot of mileage out of a rather constrained setting. Even before the branching plotlines and multiple endings, the game's trio of primary settings offer more than enough dread to deal with.

Despite its admitted inspiration in struggles with OCD and depression, Neverending Nightmares opts for a more metaphorical take on its subject matter than anything literal. The game looks at what such struggles feel like, or felt like for the creator at least, through the lens of horror rather than attempting to recount the experience directly. The bulk of the game involves waking up to an eerie, foreboding environment that only slightly changes with each return to supposed consciousness. Every wakeup is followed by a new attempt to find a way out of these increasingly imposing scenarios, searching each area for new tools to progress and usually ending in an unexpectedly horrible way. As things progress, human-but-not-quite creatures join the environment in trying to stop you, but never quite to the point of being a showdown. Even though this realm is apparently your own mind, you have no real power here.

The game's monochrome visual style is striking and memorable, with some interesting techniques used to add gloom and otherwise obfuscate areas when necessary. The only color that comes into play is red, which is used selectively but liberally for gore when warranted. The soundtrack is subtle, but haunting, and what few sounds the handful of enemies make when you encounter them are enough on their own to make it clear they should be avoided.

Neverending Nightmares does a great job of managing difficulty as well. Puzzles often rely on a bit of wandering at first to trigger certain appearances, but don't feel overly drawn out. Enemies are easy enough to avoid in most cases, with later encounters taking a bit more strategy, and the consequences for failure feel justified but horrifying. As things increase in difficulty and complexity, levels offer checkpoints to keep repetition down.

The multiple endings aren't overly numerous, and I liked how it wasn't entirely clear which one, if any of them, was the real" ending. As you finish the game
recommended: showing threads between what you've cleared thus far and making it easier to figure out where you should be looking for alternate choices to enable different progress. All in all

reviewText:
At first it seems like it takes after Lone Survivor,  but Neverending Nightmares has more in common with Dear Esther.  There's very little gaming to do.  All you do is march down long hallways, listen to the moody music, look at the creepy imagery, and eventually you get to the end.  Some may even compare it to Amnesia: The Dark Descent, but that game had plenty of things for the player to do.  It wasn't just a forced march down dark hallways; you had goals, and the monsters were actively chasing you!

Having little to do gamewise isn't necessarily a bad thing.  To The Moon was very much like this, but what set that game apart from this one is the story.  To The Moon, Lone Survivor, and Amnesia all have a complete story to uncover at the end.  Neverending Nightmares does not.  It leaves you with a bunch of confusing pieces of a story with no resolution--yet another game that thinks being vague is the same as being profound.  (I'm looking at you, Braid!)

All you do is march down long hallways, open doors, march down more long hallways, and at the end of the march is a jump-scare.  These jump-scares are effective, but after the fourth time, it becomes routine.  Oh yes, and dolls are creepy.  We get it.  Dolls *are* creepy.

Neverending Nightmares feels like it was built around its soundtrack.  The levels are ridiculously long just to make you absorb the music.  The ambient horror music makes this game, and it does a very good job creating atmosphere.  The art style is especially memorable.  I've never seen a game look like this, and it adds a lot to the creep factor.

Steam won't let me give this a neutral rating, but it deserves one.  I didn't hate this game, as it did a very good job creating atmosphere and jump-scaring me more than once, but I found the delivery more tedious than scary, and the 3 payoffs at the end do not provide a satisfying resolution to all that marching.

reviewText:
A dreamlike exploration of living with mental illness, Neverending Nightmares gets a lot of mileage out of a rather constrained setting. Even before the branching plotlines and multiple endings, the game's trio of primary settings offer more than enough dread to deal with.

Despite its admitted inspiration in struggles with OCD and depression, Neverending Nightmares opts for a more metaphorical take on its subject matter than anything literal. The game looks at what such struggles feel like, or felt like for the creator at least, through the lens of horror rather than attempting to recount the experience directly. The bulk of the game involves waking up to an eerie, foreboding environment that only slightly changes with each return to supposed consciousness. Every wakeup is followed by a new attempt to find a way out of these increasingly imposing scenarios, searching each area for new tools to progress and usually ending in an unexpectedly horrible way. As things progress, human-but-not-quite creatures join the environment in trying to stop you, but never quite to the point of being a showdown. Even though this realm is apparently your own mind, you have no real power here.

The game's monochrome visual style is striking and memorable, with some interesting techniques used to add gloom and otherwise obfuscate areas when necessary. The only color that comes into play is red, which is used selectively but liberally for gore when warranted. The soundtrack is subtle, but haunting, and what few sounds the handful of enemies make when you encounter them are enough on their own to make it clear they should be avoided.

Neverending Nightmares does a great job of managing difficulty as well. Puzzles often rely on a bit of wandering at first to trigger certain appearances, but don't feel overly drawn out. Enemies are easy enough to avoid in most cases, with later encounters taking a bit more strategy, and the consequences for failure feel justified but horrifying. As things increase in difficulty and complexity, levels offer checkpoints to keep repetition down.

The multiple endings aren't overly numerous, and I liked how it wasn't entirely clear which one, if any of them, was the real" ending. As you finish the game
recommended: showing threads between what you've cleared thus far and making it easier to figure out where you should be looking for alternate choices to enable different progress. All in all

NEN is an interesting game. I backed this on Kickstarter because the creator had an interesting idea I wanted to see flourish into a game. I purchased this and didn't immediately play it but I did save the game for my 2014 Extra-Life charity stream.

I played through, and beat, the game in about 1.5 hours. Those 1.5 hours weren't exceptionally difficult nor were they thought provoking. The only reason the things in the game meant anything to me was because I Kickstarted the game and knew that the game creator focused the game around his own anxieties and fears. This doesn't really come through in the game if you don't know those things.

I hate to base a review around the price of a game but I don't know...this is a coin toss for me. I'm going to not recommend this game. All you do is walk left or right...there aren't any puzzles, there isn't any dialogue, the scares are telegraphed and not especially scary (subjective, I know), and the short nature of the game make it really hard to recommend.

If you want to pick it up I would say get it as cheap as possible. Your mileage may vary but I felt this was a huge letdown.

reviewText:
Not much to say, you wander through locations and sometimes try to find paths around wandering things that are out to kill you or run from them.

You get the first ending after only about an hour or two depending on how slow you take it and your skill level. There's four total endings, most of which are just what doorways you go through.

Its actually the fact that they really accomplished the feel of being in a nightmare that makes me like it. Playing it, I actually remembered nightmares that I've had throughout my life and probably haven't remembered since waking up on the day after I had them.

Scared me more than a video game has since the first time I played Fatal Frame 2, and I don't know how long its been since I've seen a horror movie as scary.

Don't pay more than $8 for it, wait until there's a sale. There's not enough here for above that price.

The game actually tells you to play it with headphones, and trust me when I say it isn't for cheap jump scares but instead for more immersion. Play with the lights off and alone too, with a vibrating controller if you have it.

reviewText:
I've wanted to play Neverending Nightmares for quite some time, and now that I have I can say that I really enjoyed it.

The first thing that drew me in was the art style, it's a little different to a lot of what's out there, especially within the genre. The art style is also very fitting for the game and its subject matter. Then the story itself was intriguing to me, as someone fascinated with dreams and nightmares who experiences a lot of both the premise meant the game was bound to interest me.

Yes, the game is rather short, but I don't think that's necessarily a bad thing. I often enjoy short games, they can be just the thing when you fancy playing something but have other things going on. It also keeps the game from being repetitive, in order to make this game longer a lot of new creatures and endings would have needed to be added, by which point the plot would run the risk of getting stretched too thin. I feel like Neverending Nightmares strikes the perfect balance for those who don't mind if a game is short.

As far as how scary this game is, that'd depend on what gets to you, for instance, for a person afraid of dolls a large portion of this game would be very creepy. For me there were other things that would creep me out, I'm afraid of the dark and stairs make me very uneasy. They have covered a lot of based and there were a couple of bits where I jumped (although I'm admittedly easily startled).

Lastly, I'd say that while I definitely recommend this game to people who don't mind a short psychological horror experience that isn't action-oriented, if you are sensitive to imagery or references to suicide or self harm then this game will likely not be for you, so basically, player discretion is advised.

reviewText:
As gaming matures so does it’s themes. In recent years there has been a slew of more or less interactive games about mental illnesses, perhaps the most discussed being Depression Quest.
Neverending Nightmares is also said to be based on the developers own experience living with ocd and depression, but where Depression Quest was a choose-your-own-adventure text based game this time we have a proper adventure game.
Or what at first glance looks like a proper game. Yes there is a character to control and progress to be made but don’t be fooled to think there is much more gameplay here.
The whole game consists of walking endless corridors, sometimes opening doors or clumsily trying to avoid a few monsters.

The striking art style is admirable, in still pictures it resembles some crude underground comic from yesteryear and in motion the facial expressions and body language of the main character helps transfer a feeling of utter despair and terror as you blindly navigate the endless corridors.
But here also lies it’s main problem - sure the atmosphere is there but it’s not used to tell the gamer anything, the story is non-existent until the very end.
While I can sympathise with the design decision to keep with the theme of a looping, never ending nightmare it also takes away the incentive to keep playing as you are not given any reason to do so. In the end it was an empty experience more filled with boredom than horror.

reviewText:
Before I started I didn't know much about Neverending Nightmares. I thought it was another horror game for me, as a huge fan of horror, to consume. It is said you shouldn't expect something from a game when you don't know anything about it. But the excitment got the better of me. It was the unigue artwork in the screenshots that got my attention big time. I expected ( or was hoping ) some good scares, a good story, clever gameplay and maybe even puzzles. I was so stupid to think like this because when I eventually played I was let down by my own expectations.

Thomas is a boy ( or a young man, can't really tell ) who is experiencing terrible nightmares which never seem to end. As he wanders around his nightmares looking for a way out he sometimes comes across these monsters which will instantly kill him if they get too close. Everything is very straightforward; passing through multiple dark hallways and rooms, sometimes with a candle on hand and sometimes not. And sometimes he will find his sister which results in either one of them  experiencing something grisly.

Like I said the artstyle is what made me so interested. Black and white with occasional colour to draw the attention of the player to a certain object. There is gore involved so when blood is on the walls or the innards of someone out, it's of course very red. In my silly opinion the art looks like it could on a book. If it wasn't so dark or so gory I could imagine this kind of art being in a children's book. And I mean this in a positive way. I've seen a lot of people mention Edward Gorey ( I didn't know about him before ) and there was one developer who confirmed they got inspiration from his work.

The artstyle is where the positives end up, unfortunately. Earlier I described the nightmares as being terrible but the thing is that in Neverending Nightmares they really aren't. If I had to describe NN with one word it would be simply boring. Mind-numbningly boring. I played at night, just like I always do horror games to keep myself on the edge, and I almost fell asleep. I was immensely bored and annoyed. I know what is it like to have depression because I suffered from it. And I regularly get nightmares. But I think this game isn't able to properly convey the feelings of such dread, even if the lead designer became inspired by his own struggles. I didn't expect my experience to be filled with jumpscares because honestly I don't like them either. But there was basically nothing happening throughout my playthrough and it made me annoyed. And when something did happen, something very small ( that's what it felt like anyway ), it revoked no kind of emotion in me.

A big problem is that there is no context for anything happening. You are just this boy roaming in his own nightmares, encountering random monsters and looking for his sister ( or in the next nightmare she was not his sister ). And then when he does find her it ends in something bad and the end. Why? What? When? Who? All this in just under two hours. And despite being so short I felt it was too long. Too much padding by making you walk through same looking rooms and hallways over and over. Too long because it felt like nothing happened.

Neverending Nightmares is so short that after completing it and all the achievements I had to idle couple of hours more to get my trading cards. This would have been absolutely fine if the experience had been worth it; one of my favourite video games happens to be Brothers: A Tale of Two Sons and it's short as well. It's a wonder I managed to write this much about a game that is shorter than two hours but I guess it's just my disappointment speaking.

Personal Rating: 2/5 - Negative
